newsitem.title: SYRIA: Syria expects to double oil, gas reserves.
newsitem.headline: Syria expects to double oil, gas reserves.

text.p: Syria expects to more than double its proven oil and gas reserves when structures believed to contain oil and gas are drilled, a senior oil official said on Tuesday.

"Seismic, gravity, magnetic, electro-magnatic, remote sensing pictures and geological survey enabled us to discover prosperous surface and sub-surface structures but so far only 293 were drilled and about 160 gave oil and gas production," Hussein Makarem of the Syrian Petroleum Company (SPC) said.
"The structures are considered as important as the other structures where oil was found with good quanities," he said, speaking at a seminar on geological activities.
Makarem said that several international oil companies were negotiating to obtain exploration licences in Syria.
He gave no figures, but according to recent estimates Syria had around 2.5 billion barrels of proven oil reserves and 7,000 billion cubic feet of gas.

"In the prosperous structures we expect the existance (of) double the discovered oil reserves and more than double the gas reserves.. This means the oil industry in Syria has a bright future," Makarem said.
But he said that confirmation of that would require detailed studies and large investment over several years.
Makarem said that since the begining of production in 1967 until early this year Syria's total production of oil reached 338 million cubic metres (2.436 billion barrels).
Production of gas of all types during the same period reached 39.5 billion cubic metres (1394 billion cubic feet).
Makarem said that in 1968 Syria's production of mainly heavy oil in the far north-eastern fields stood at 1.13 million cubic metres per year (8.16 million bpd).
Production rose to 8.8 million cubic metres per year (150,000 bpd by 1995, he said.

Starting from 1985 Syria began production of light oil from oilfields in central Syria extending to the eastern parts of the country, close to the Iraqi border, with a rate of 500,000 cubic metres per year (3.4 million barrels per year).
This developed later to reach 20 million cubic metres (125.6 million barrels per year) in 1995.
Syria currently produces around an avarage 600,000 barrels per day of which over 330,000 bpd are exported
